title: France’s Penaud scores twice in win for Rugby World Cup hosts over Australia
description:
• France 41-17 Australia
  • Damian Penaud scores two tries in Les Bleus’ final warm-up

Two tries from the flying wing Damian Penaud helped the World Cup hosts, France, complete their preparations for the tournament with a 41-17 victory over Australia, the Wallabies’ fifth successive defeat.

It was the kind of statement the French would have been hoping to make less than a fortnight before they kick off the World Cup against the All Blacks at the same Stade de France venue, although they outscored the youthful Australia team by only four tries to three.

Continue reading...

title: Aaron Rodgers caps brief New York Jets preseason debut with touchdown pass
description:
• Rodgers plays two series in first preseason game since 2018
  • Four-time MVP throws 14-yard TD to wideout Garrett Wilson
  • Jets open regular season at Buffalo Bills on 11 September

Aaron Rodgers shook off the rust, threw a few passes and led the New York Jets into the end zone.

It all made for a successful preseason debut with his new team. And Jets fans can breathe a sigh of relief.

Continue reading...

title: When I was young, I saw my mother as a tyrant. Now I see myself in her photograph
description:
Author Yen-Rong Wong has been hesitant to write about her mother – but as she sees her mother in her own reflection, she’s been forced to reconcile her memories of the past

  • Get our weekend culture and lifestyle email

I once found a photo of my mother as a young woman while I was trying to find photos of myself as a child. I was struck by how similar we looked – the structure and shape of our faces, the positioning of our hair and our facial features. I wondered what a colourised version of the photo would look like. When I mentioned this to my mother, she brushed it off. “Out of the two of you, you were always the one who looked more like me,” she said.

French psychoanalyst and psychiatrist Jacques Lacan proposed that all children pass through a stage of development where they learn to recognise themselves in their own reflection. He called it the mirror stage, and argued that it “illustrates the conflictual nature of the dual relationship”⁠: that is, the relationship between the person you are and the person you see when you look in the mirror. But what happens when you look in the mirror and you see your mother? Or, what happens if you look at your mother and you see yourself?

Continue reading...
